awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  ABI Development: Building a Community Gateway for Cryo-Electron Microscopy Structure Determination
awd_abstract_narration:
Structural biology, the field devoted to understanding the chemical underpinnings of life, is undergoing a revolution due to the emergence, over the last 4 years, of cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) as a technique capable of producing atomic-resolution structures. This "resolution revolution" has placed within reach structures that were previously inaccessible with other structural biology techniques. As a consequence, there is a growing interest among scientists in the expanded capabilities of cryo-EM. While previous generations of cryo-EM users were familiar with Linux and the HPC tools necessary to process the data, this is not the case with many of the structural biologists now attracted to the technique. We see this as a major barrier to the growth of cryo-EM. In order to remove this barrier, this project will develop an easy-to-use web platform, or "science gateway",  that will interface with HPC resources, data processing algorithms, and long-term data storage options, allowing inexperienced users to access the full potential of cryo-EM. A prototype gateway (COSMIC2: Cryo-EM Open Source Multiplatform Infrastructure for Cloud Computing) has been developed in collaboration with the San Diego Supercomputer Center (SDSC), using its substantial HPC resources. This project will turn this early prototype into a resource that will benefit the structural biology community nationwide and outline all the features of a fully-developed gateway. 

The proposed COSMIC2 gateway will provide a large pool of computing time for cryo-EM users through an XSEDE allocation to the PIs; an easy-to-use web portal allowing users to select cryo-EM analysis routines; novel algorithms to streamline data processing, removing manual user intervention; mechanisms for viewing output data through the web interface; and long-term data storage solutions by connecting COSMIC2 to cloud storage providers (e.g. Google Drive, Box). The COSMIC2 gateway will optimally install and test major cryo-EM data processing software to ensure that they are using computational resources efficiently. The transformative impact of this project will come from the adoption of the COSMIC2 gateway by the broad structural biology community, to which it will bring national HPC resources and the power of cryo-EM while the removing any obstacles in accessing them. The current prototype for the resource may be seen at http://cosmic-cryoem.org/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Structural biology is the field dedicated to determining and interpreting how the structure of nanometer-sized molecular machines affects macromolecular function, cell survival, and organism evolution. Innovations in cryo-EM, an experimental structural biology technique, and protein structure prediction, a theoretical structural biology technique, have pushed structural biology into the spotlight for life sciences researchers across the globe. 

Despite the power of cryo-EM and structure prediction, advanced cyberinfrastructure is required to enable users to access these techniques. For instance, in cryo-EM, hundreds of thousands of “particle” images must be computationally aligned and reconstructed hundreds of times for a single dataset during data analysis. In structure prediction, AlphaFold2 requires ~2.2 TB of genetic databases on fast storage arrays to be interrogated during structure prediction by both CPU and GPU-driven calculations. 

COSMIC2 is a science gateway that has empowered scientists and students worldwide to use structural biology tools. As of 10/1/2024, 9,018 users have created accounts on COSMIC2, where 318 new user accounts are created monthly. These users have submitted 36,438 jobs that range from structure prediction to cryo-EM and hail from 84 different countries. Notably, we have seen COSMIC2 used for both undergraduate and graduate student classes, highlighting the importance of COSMIC2 as an educational tool.  Finally, published literature has cited the COSMIC2 gateway, which has been cited 115 times in various journals such as the Journal of Cell Biology, Cell, and Nature Structural and Molecular Biology. 

A core philosophy of COSMIC2 has been helping users of all backgrounds access the resources without administrative overhead. As such, we collect institutional information per user without asking for further details. Each user receives 60 GPU hours of computing time, allowing them to run many jobs before requesting additional time. 

A subset of users (115 out of 9,018) were major users of COSMIC2, requiring more than 60 GPU-hours for their jobs. All major users must provide grant numbers and information about the head of their laboratory. Analysis of the past 12 months of major users showed that COSMIC2 supported 139 grants worldwide. For US-based researchers, COSMIC2 has been used for 83 grants from federal funding agencies such as the NSF, NIH, DOE, and DOD, in addition to private agencies such as HHMI, Welch Foundation, and the Simon’s Foundation. Within the NSF, grants from the Divisions of Molecular and Cellular Biology, Chemistry, Integrative Organismal Systems, and Emerging Frontiers, along with the Office of Strategic Initiatives, have used the COSMIC2 gateway. Internationally, major users of COSMIC2 were directly linked to 56 grants from agencies such as the European Research Council, British Heart Foundation, Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada, and the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research. 

Overall, COSMIC2 has emerged as a go-to science gateway for structural biology. The funding of COSMIC2 has empowered thousands of students, researchers, and faculty worldwide with easy-to-use, point-and-click access to state-of-the-art software tools for structural biology.
